ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: The clinician asked If I had questions or concerns
The clinician helped with concerns related to the use of medication
The clinician was friendly during initial visit
The clinician gave clear instructions on how to take medication
The clinician listened to you
The clinician gave clear explanation about how medication would affect you
The clinician talked about things that you could to to help you feel better
The clinician gave written information about medication
The clinician scheduled a follow-up appointment
Total Clinician Initial Communication Style
Notes: Sum of items css_a1-css_a9; higher scores indicate a more initial collaborative communication style

ElementDescription: The clinician encourages expression of problems
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neither; 4= Agree; 5= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: The clinician asks about concerns
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neither; 4= Agree; 5= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: The clinician listens to your concerns
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neither; 4= Agree; 5= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: The clinician helped solve problems
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neither; 4= Agree; 5= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Total Clinician Follow-up Communication Style
Notes: Sum of items css_b1-css_b4; higher scores indicate a more participatory problem-solving manner and closer monitoring of medication use
